Support for the Establishment of a Supplementary Pension System (KSTA MON 52151) 
 
TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
1.  The  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  will  engage  consultants  following  the  ADB 
Procurement  Policy  (2017,  as  amended  from  time  to  time)  and  its  associated  project 
administration instructions and/or staff instructions. Technical assistance (TA) proceeds will be 
disbursed in accordance with ADB’s Technical Assistance Disbursement Handbook (2010, as 
amended from time to time). Consultants will be engaged individually. All technical reports will be 
submitted in English and Mongolian to ADB and the executing agency, in both hard and electronic 
copies. 
 
2.  Pension Law Specialist (international, 3 person-months, intermittent). The specialist will 
(i) ideally have at least 15 years of experience with legal and regulatory drafting around pension 
schemes and funds; (ii) hold a master’s degree or higher qualification in a relevant law subject; 
(iii) be proficient in English; and (iv) have experience with providing consulting services to the 
Government of Mongolia. As the team leader, the specialist will be accountable to ADB for the 
final outputs of this TA, as well as the daily coordination and supervision of the team. The 
specialist will perform the following: 
 
(i)  develop an overall approach and implementation plan, in consultation with the 
executing and implementing agencies; 
(ii)  develop the outline of TA inception, interim, and final reports; and assign work to 
respective specialists; 
(iii)  draft a new proposed Law on Supplementary Pension Savings (LSPS) addressing, 
inter alia, the benefit structure and method for the payment of benefits and the 
provision of matching contributions for individuals not participating in the public 
social insurance system; 
(iv)  draft revisions to the Personal Income Tax Law, the Labor Laws, Personal Income 
Tax, the Law on Investment Funds and the Law on Social Insurance; and 
(v)  undertake  other  legal  an  managerial  tasks  necessary  to  accomplish  the  TA 
objectives. 
 
3.  Actuarial Specialist (international, 1 person-month, intermittent). The specialist will be a 
qualified actuary, ideally with at least 10 years of experience with actuarial valuation of pension 
schemes. The specific responsibilities will include the following: 
 
(i)  determine long-term actuarial cost of the existing pension scheme and advise 
different funding approaches considering the financial constraints and specific 
circumstances in Mongolia; 
(ii)  recommend  necessary  policy,  procedures,  and  formulation  of  constitutive 
document for the establishment of private pension funds; 
(iii)  formulate investment policy, procedural documents, processes and investment 
performance measurement mechanism of the proposed pension fund; 
(iv)  determine projected pension payments including commutation for the next 30 
years; 
(v)  project the pension scheme cash flows including the accumulation of pension 
fund; and 
(vi)  conduct other related tasks assigned by the team leader.  
 
4.  Pension Policy Specialist (international, 3 person-months, intermittent). The pension 
policy specialist will have at least 10 years of experience working in the pension and social 
insurance market. The specialist’s responsibilities will include the development of:

Support for the Establishment of a Supplementary Pension System (KSTA MON 52151) 
 
 
(i)  a  framework  of  standards  for  the  establishment,  licensing,  operation  and 
supervision of Employer Sponsored Supplementary Pension Plans;  
(ii)  specific  standards  to  control  the  investment  portfolios,  manage  risks  in  the 
investment process, present results and credit individual accounts with investment 
returns that would apply to Pension Investment Funds for inclusion in the Law on 
Investment Funds;  
(iii)  a  comprehensive  prudential  framework—including  regulatory  oversight  and 
redress mechanisms—that applies to Pension Investment Funds for inclusion in 
the new law on Supplementary Pension Savings; and 
(iv)  conduct other related tasks assigned by the team leader. 
 
5.  Communication  Specialist  (international,  3  person-months,  intermittent).  The 
communication specialist ideally will have at least 10 years of working experience in project 
communication,  and  the  design  and  implementation  of  awareness  and  behavioral  change 
campaigns. A good understanding of Mongolia’s social-cultural environment is a significant 
advantage. The specialist will have an advanced degree in (Mass) Communication. The specialist 
will: 
 
(i)  conduct a stakeholders’ analysis to identify and map key stakeholders, their level 
of influence, communication dynamics, relative positions and vested interests.  The 
stakeholder analysis will consider policy makers, private sector stakeholders, civil 
society organizations and (potential) consumers; 
(ii)  conduct a communication assessment to evaluate the communication capacity 
and  media  influence  and  presence  of  the  key  stakeholders  to  manage  the 
implementation  of  the  communication  program.  The  assessment  will  include 
analyses of how the stakeholders receive and process information from, but not 
limited to, mainstream media outlets, local forms of information dissemination 
practices, new media and technology; 
(iii)  analyze the communication channels that will be critical to sharing information, 
enabling feedback and participation, building consensus and otherwise supporting 
project objectives; and 
(iv)  conduct other related tasks assigned by the team leader. 
 
6.  Econometrist (national, 1 person-month, intermittent). The specialist will have strong 
quantitative and modelling skills, with preferably at least 5 years of relevant working experience 
and a master’s degree in econometrics. The specialist will:  
 
(i)  work in close collaboration with the actuarial specialist, and will support this 
specialist in the tasks assigned to him/her; 
(ii)  play  a  lead  role  in  the  design  and  implementation  of  training  activities  for 
government officials and private sector stakeholders; 
(iii)  provide, where necessary, interpretation services during technical meetings with 
stakeholders; and 
(iv)  conduct other related tasks assigned by the actuarial specialist or team leader. 
 
7.  Tax Lawyer (national, 4 person-months, intermittent). The specialist will have a strong 
understanding of the current legal and regulatory regime around pension and social insurance 
schemes in Mongolia, with preferably at least 5 years of relevant working experience and a 
master’s degree in law. The specialist will:

(i)  work in close collaboration with the pension laywer, and will support this specialist 
in the tasks assigned to him/her; 
(ii)  play  a  lead  role  in  the  design  and  implementation  of  training  activities  for 
government officials and private sector stakeholders; 
(iii)  provide, where necessary, interpretation services during technical meetings with 
stakeholders; and 
(iv)  conduct other related tasks assigned by the pension law specialist or team leader. 
 
7.  Accountant/Management Consultant (national, 4 person-months, intermittent). The 
specialist  will  have  a  strong  understanding  of  the  current  institutional  and  organizational 
arrangements around pension and social insurance schemes in Mongolia; a good understanding 
of the control and risk management criteria around investment portfolios; preferably with at least 
5 years of relevant working experience and a certified public accountant. The specialist will: 
 
(i)  work in close collaboration with the pension policy specialist, and will support this 
specialist in the tasks assigned to him/her; 
(ii)  play  a  lead  role  in  the  design  and  implementation  of  training  activities  for 
government officials and private sector stakeholders; 
(iii)  provide, where necessary, interpretation services during technical meetings with 
stakeholders; and 
(iv)  conduct other related tasks assigned by the pension policy specialist or team 
leader. 
 
8.  Communications Specialist (national, 4 person-months, intermittent). The specialist will 
have  solid,  proven  track-record  in  the  design  and  implementation  of  communication  and 
behavioral change campaigns in Mongolia; a basic understanding of the current pension and 
social insurance schemes in Mongolia; a master’s degree in communication. The specialist will: 
 
(i)  work in close collaboration with the international communication specialist, and will 
support this specialist in the tasks assigned to him/her; 
(ii)  play  a  lead  role  in  the  design  and  implementation  of  training  activities  for 
government officials and private sector stakeholders; 
(iii)  provide, where necessary, interpretation services during technical meetings with 
stakeholders; and 
(iv)  conduct other related tasks assigned by the international communication specialist 
or team leader.
